objectives: Learn to count and recognize numbers from 1 to 100.
Identify and name basic colors commonly seen around us.
Memorize the names of the days of the week and months of the year.

sections.text: Numbers help us count things like how many students are in the class or how many animals are on the farm. Let's start with counting from 1 to 10.
usage_examples: I have one book in my bag.
There are two bullocks in our field.
My family has three members.
We saw four birds on the tree.
I have five fingers on one hand.

sections.text: After ten, we continue counting. These numbers are a little different, but easy to learn.
usage_examples: There are eleven players in a cricket team.
I am twelve years old.
There are thirteen students present today.
We have fourteen mangoes in the basket.
There are fifteen cows in our village.

sections.text: From twenty-one, we combine the tens (twenty, thirty, forty, fifty) with numbers from one to nine.
usage_examples: Our classroom has twenty-one desks.
There are thirty students in my class.
My father is forty-five years old.
Our village has about fifty houses.
I scored twenty-five marks in the test.

sections.text: The pattern continues from fifty-one to one hundred. Practice these to count larger groups of things.
usage_examples: My grandmother is fifty-five years old.
There are sixty minutes in one hour.
The distance to the city is seventy-three kilometers.
We collected eighty-eight apples from the orchard.
There are one hundred pages in this notebook.

sections.text: Colors make our world beautiful! We see many colors in nature and around our homes and school.

examples.label: Red
examples.value: The color of ripe tomatoes, blood, or some flowers. It is a bright, strong color.

examples.label: Blue
examples.value: The color of a clear sky or the ocean. It is a cool and calm color.

examples.label: Green
examples.value: The color of grass, leaves, and most plants. It is the color of nature and freshness.

examples.label: Yellow
examples.value: The color of the sun, lemons, or some ripe mangoes. It is a bright and happy color.

examples.label: Black
examples.value: The darkest color, like the night sky without stars or charcoal. It absorbs all light.

examples.label: White
examples.value: The lightest color, like milk, snow, or clouds. It reflects all light.

examples.label: Brown
examples.value: The color of soil, wood, or tree trunks. It is a common color in nature.

examples.label: Orange
examples.value: The color of an orange fruit or a marigold flower. It is a warm and energetic color.

examples.label: Pink
examples.value: A light shade of red. Many flowers are pink.

examples.label: Purple
examples.value: The color of a brinjal (eggplant) or some grapes. It is a mix of red and blue.

examples.label: Grey
examples.value: The color of ash or a cloudy sky. It is a mix of black and white.

usage_examples: My school uniform has a red stripe.
The sky is blue today.
Our fields are green with new crops.
The sun is yellow and bright.
The blackboard is black.
My shirt is white and clean.
The soil in our village is brown.
The marigold flowers in the garden are orange.
My little sister has a pink dress.
The brinjal curry my mother cooks is purple.
The smoke from the fire is grey.

sections.text: There are seven days in a week. Knowing them helps us talk about when things happen, like school days or market days.

examples.label: Monday
examples.value: The first day of the school week after the weekend.

examples.label: Tuesday
examples.value: The day after Monday.

examples.label: Wednesday
examples.value: The middle day of the school week.

examples.label: Thursday
examples.value: The day before Friday.

examples.label: Friday
examples.value: The last day of the school week before the weekend.

examples.label: Saturday
examples.value: The first day of the weekend, a holiday for many.

examples.label: Sunday
examples.value: The second day of the weekend, often a day for rest or family.

usage_examples: Today is Monday, so we have English class.
We play sports on Tuesday afternoons.
The village market is on Wednesday.
I visit my grandparents every Thursday.
School closes for the weekend on Friday.
We clean our house on Saturday.
Sunday is a holiday, and we go to the temple.

table.title: Days of the Week
rows: Second day of the weekend, often a rest day

sections.text: These words help us talk about time relative to 'now'.

examples.label: Today
examples.value: The present day; the day we are currently in.

examples.label: Tomorrow
examples.value: The day after today.

examples.label: Yesterday
examples.value: The day before today.

usage_examples: Today, I have my Maths exam.
Tomorrow, we will visit the village fair.
Yesterday, I played cricket with my friends.
What are you doing today?
Tomorrow is my sister's birthday.
We had a holiday yesterday.

sections.text: There are twelve months in one year. Each month has about 30 or 31 days. Knowing them helps us mark important events like festivals and birthdays.

examples.label: January
examples.value: The first month of the year, often cold.

examples.label: February
examples.value: The second month, shortest month with 28 or 29 days.

examples.label: March
examples.value: The third month, when spring starts and fields become green again. [2]

examples.label: April
examples.value: The fourth month, often with some rain or hotter weather starting. [2]

examples.label: May
examples.value: The fifth month, usually very hot, often the start of summer vacation. [2]

examples.label: June
examples.value: The sixth month, when the monsoon season often begins. [2]

examples.label: July
examples.value: The seventh month, often with heavy rains. [2]

examples.label: August
examples.value: The eighth month, another rainy month in many places. [2]

examples.label: September
examples.value: The ninth month, when schools often start after a break. [2]

examples.label: October
examples.value: The tenth month, many festivals like Diwali and Dussehra are celebrated. [2]

examples.label: November
examples.value: The eleventh month, the weather starts to get cooler. [2]

examples.label: December
examples.value: The twelfth and last month of the year, often a cold month.

usage_examples: My school reopens in July.
Our main festival is celebrated in October.
My birthday is in May.
The harvest season is usually in March.
The new year starts in January.
We have a long holiday in December.
It rains a lot in August.

sections.text: These words help us measure time from very short to very long periods.

examples.label: Second
examples.value: A very short unit of time. There are 60 seconds in a minute. [2]

examples.label: Minute
examples.value: A unit of time equal to 60 seconds. [2]

examples.label: Hour
examples.value: A unit of time equal to 60 minutes. [2]

examples.label: Day
examples.value: A period of 24 hours. [2]

examples.label: Week
examples.value: A period of seven days. [2]

examples.label: Fortnight
examples.value: A period of two weeks or 14 days.

examples.label: Month
examples.value: A period of about 30 days or 4 weeks. [2]

examples.label: Year
examples.value: A period of 12 months or 365 days. [2]

examples.label: Decade
examples.value: A period of ten years. [2, 4]

examples.label: Century
examples.value: A period of one hundred years. [2, 4]

examples.label: Millennium
examples.value: A period of one thousand years. [2]

examples.label: Moment
examples.value: A very brief period of time. [4]

examples.label: Period
examples.value: A length or portion of time.

examples.label: Era
examples.value: A long and distinct period of history with a particular feature. [4]

examples.label: Age
examples.value: A distinct period in history.

usage_examples: Wait a second, I am coming.
I will be there in five minutes.
The school is one hour away.
I will see you the day after tomorrow.
We have a holiday next week.
My uncle will visit us for a fortnight.
My birthday is next month.
A new year brings new hope.
Many things changed in the last decade.
This temple was built a century ago.
A millennium is a very long time.
He thought for a moment before answering.
The rainy period will begin soon.
It was an era of peace and prosperity.
The Stone Age was a very early period of human history.

sections.text: These words describe how often or how fast something happens.

examples.label: Always
examples.value: At all times; on every occasion. [14]

examples.label: Often
examples.value: Many times; frequently.

examples.label: Usually
examples.value: In the way that is most common or normal. [14]

examples.label: Sometimes
examples.value: On some occasions but not all the time. [14]

examples.label: Rarely
examples.value: Not often; seldom. [14]

examples.label: Never
examples.value: At no time in the past or future. [14]

examples.label: Daily
examples.value: Happening or done every day.

examples.label: Weekly
examples.value: Happening or done every week.

examples.label: Monthly
examples.value: Happening or done every month.

examples.label: Annually
examples.value: Happening once every year.

examples.label: Fast
examples.value: Moving at a high speed.

examples.label: Slow
examples.value: Moving at a low speed.

examples.label: Quick
examples.value: Happening in a short time.

examples.label: Gradual
examples.value: Taking place slowly over a period of time.

examples.label: Sudden
examples.value: Happening quickly and unexpectedly.

usage_examples: You should always tell the truth.
I often go to the temple with my grandmother.
We usually have dinner at 8 p.m.
Sometimes, we play inside the house.
He rarely comes to the village.
I have never seen a tiger.
The milkman comes daily.
The village market is held weekly.
We get a monthly magazine.
The school has its annual function in December.
A cheetah can run very fast.
The bullock cart is a slow vehicle.
She gave a quick reply.
There has been a gradual improvement in his health.
The sudden rain surprised everyone.

sections.text: A day is divided into different parts based on the position of the sun. [1]

examples.label: Morning
examples.value: The period from sunrise to noon. [3]

examples.label: Afternoon
examples.value: The time from noon or lunchtime until evening. [3]

examples.label: Evening
examples.value: The period at the end of the day, usually from about 6 p.m. to bedtime. [1]

examples.label: Night
examples.value: The period from sunset to sunrise when it is dark. [3]

examples.label: Daytime
examples.value: The period when there is daylight, from sunrise to sunset. [3]

examples.label: Night-time
examples.value: The period when it is night.

usage_examples: The birds chirp in the morning.
I take a nap in the afternoon.
We light the lamps in the evening.
The stars shine at night.
In the daytime, the village is full of activity.
Owls are active during the night-time.

sections.text: These words refer to the transitional times at the beginning and end of daylight.

examples.label: Dawn
examples.value: The first appearance of light in the sky before sunrise. [3]

examples.label: Sunrise
examples.value: The time in the morning when the sun appears over the horizon. [3]

examples.label: Noon
examples.value: The middle of the day; twelve o'clock. [3]

examples.label: Midday
examples.value: Another word for noon, the middle of the day. [3]

examples.label: Sunset
examples.value: The time in the evening when the sun disappears below the horizon. [3]

examples.label: Dusk
examples.value: The time at the end of the day just before it gets dark. [3]

examples.label: Twilight
examples.value: The soft, glowing light from the sky when the sun is below the horizon, just after sunset or before sunrise. [3]

examples.label: Midnight
examples.value: The middle of the night; twelve o'clock at night. [3]

usage_examples: The farmer woke up at dawn to go to the fields.
The view of the sunrise from the hill is beautiful.
We eat our lunch at noon.
The sun is directly overhead at midday.
The cows return home at sunset.
It gets cool at dusk.
The sky was a beautiful orange during twilight.
The street was empty at midnight.

sections.text: These words help describe how light or dark a color is.

examples.label: Light
examples.value: A color that is pale or not dark, like light blue or light green.

examples.label: Dark
examples.value: A color that is closer to black than white, like dark red or dark brown.

examples.label: Pale
examples.value: A color that is very light, lacking intensity. [11]

examples.label: Deep
examples.value: A color that is very dark and rich. [18]

examples.label: Shade
examples.value: A variety of a color made by adding black to it. [16]

examples.label: Tint
examples.value: A variety of a color made by adding white to it. [16]

examples.label: Tone
examples.value: A variety of a color made by adding grey to it. [16]

usage_examples: The sky is a light blue color.
The forest looks dark at night.
She wore a pale yellow sari.
The well is very deep and dark.
This is a darker shade of green.
Pink is a tint of red.
The wall is painted in a soft tone of grey.

sections.text: These words describe how strong a color is or what it looks like.

examples.label: Bright
examples.value: A color that is strong and easy to see; full of light.

examples.label: Dull
examples.value: A color that is not bright or shiny. [11]

examples.label: Vivid
examples.value: A color that is very bright and clear. [11, 18]

examples.label: Rich
examples.value: A color that is strong and deep. [18]

examples.label: Warm
examples.value: Colors like red, yellow, and orange that make you think of heat. [9, 17]

examples.label: Cool
examples.value: Colors like blue, green, and purple that make you think of cold. [9]

examples.label: Neutral
examples.value: Colors that are not on the color wheel, like black, white, grey, and brown. [9]

examples.label: Shiny
examples.value: Reflecting light; bright.

examples.label: Matte
examples.value: Not shiny; dull.

examples.label: Colorful
examples.value: Having many different colors.

examples.label: Plain
examples.value: Having only one color and no pattern.

examples.label: Patterned
examples.value: Having a repeated decorative design.

examples.label: Striped
examples.value: Marked with lines or bands of color.

examples.label: Spotted
examples.value: Marked with round dots.

examples.label: Transparent
examples.value: You can see through it, like glass.

usage_examples: The peacock has bright feathers.
The color of the old wall is dull.
The painting was full of vivid colors.
She likes rich, dark colors.
Red is a warm color.
Blue is a cool color.
The soil is a neutral brown color.
The new pot is very shiny.
The wall has a matte finish.
The butterfly is very colorful.
My shirt is plain white.
She wore a patterned dress.
The tiger is a striped animal.
The deer has a spotted coat.
Water is transparent.

sections.text: A year is divided into different seasons, each with its own weather. In India, we often experience six seasons. [7]

examples.label: Spring (Vasant)
examples.value: The season when flowers bloom and new leaves appear. The weather is pleasant. [5, 6]

examples.label: Summer (Grishma)
examples.value: The hottest season of the year, with long and sunny days. [5, 6]

examples.label: Monsoon (Varsha)
examples.value: The rainy season, when we get a lot of rainfall. [6, 7]

examples.label: Autumn (Sharad)
examples.value: The season when trees shed their leaves and the weather starts to cool down. [5, 6]

examples.label: Pre-Winter (Hemant)
examples.value: The season just before winter when it starts to get cold. [7]

examples.label: Winter (Shishir)
examples.value: The coldest season of the year, with short days and long nights. [5, 6]

usage_examples: The garden looks beautiful in spring.
We eat mangoes and ice cream in summer.
Farmers wait for the monsoon to plant their crops.
The ground is covered with dry leaves in autumn.
We start wearing light sweaters in the pre-winter season.
People sit around a fire to keep warm in winter.

sections.text: These words help us talk about the kind of weather in different seasons.

examples.label: Hot
examples.value: Having a high temperature; what we feel in summer.

examples.label: Cold
examples.value: Having a low temperature; what we feel in winter.

examples.label: Warm
examples.value: Pleasantly high temperature; not too hot.

examples.label: Cool
examples.value: Pleasantly low temperature; not too cold.

examples.label: Humid
examples.value: Feeling wet or damp in the air, especially during monsoon. [2]

examples.label: Dry
examples.value: Having little or no rain.

examples.label: Sunny
examples.value: With bright sunshine and no clouds.

examples.label: Cloudy
examples.value: When the sky is covered with clouds.

examples.label: Rainy
examples.value: When rain is falling.

examples.label: Windy
examples.value: With a lot of wind blowing.

examples.label: Stormy
examples.value: With strong winds, heavy rain, and sometimes thunder and lightning.

examples.label: Foggy
examples.value: Full of thick cloud-like air close to the ground, common in winter mornings.

examples.label: Pleasant
examples.value: Nice and enjoyable weather.

examples.label: Harsh
examples.value: Very severe and unpleasant weather.

examples.label: Mild
examples.value: Gentle weather, not extreme.

usage_examples: It is very hot in the afternoon.
Wear warm clothes on a cold day.
The morning sun feels warm on the skin.
A cool breeze is blowing.
The air is very humid during the rainy season.
The weather is very dry in May.
Let's play outside on this sunny day.
It looks like it will rain on this cloudy day.
I love the sound of a rainy afternoon.
It is difficult to walk on a windy day.
The sea becomes rough during stormy weather.
The roads are not visible on a foggy morning.
The weather in spring is very pleasant.
The summer sun can be very harsh.
The winter in our village is usually mild.

sections.text: Words that describe time in relation to now, the past, or the future.

examples.label: Now
examples.value: At the present time or moment. [14]

examples.label: Then
examples.value: At that time (in the past or future).

examples.label: Today
examples.value: This present day. [19]

examples.label: Yesterday
examples.value: The day before today. [14]

examples.label: Tomorrow
examples.value: The day after today. [14]

examples.label: Tonight
examples.value: The evening or night of the present day.

examples.label: The day before yesterday
examples.value: Two days ago.

examples.label: The day after tomorrow
examples.value: In two days' time.

examples.label: This week
examples.value: The current week. [19]

examples.label: Last week
examples.value: The week before the present one. [14]

examples.label: Next week
examples.value: The week after the present one. [14]

examples.label: Current
examples.value: Happening or being used or done now.

examples.label: Recent
examples.value: Having happened or started only a short time ago.

examples.label: Previous
examples.value: Existing or happening before the present time.

examples.label: Upcoming
examples.value: Happening soon; forthcoming.

usage_examples: I am busy right now.
I was in school then.
What is the date today?
We had a guest yesterday.
Tomorrow is a holiday.
We will watch a movie tonight.
I met him the day before yesterday.
The results will be out the day after tomorrow.
I have a test this week.
I was unwell last week.
My uncle will come next week.
What is the current time?
There has been a recent change in the weather.
The previous owner sold the house.
Are you prepared for the upcoming exam?

sections.text: Words that connect events in time or show their duration.

examples.label: Before
examples.value: At an earlier time. [19]

examples.label: After
examples.value: At a later time. [19]

examples.label: During
examples.value: Throughout the whole of a period of time. [14]

examples.label: While
examples.value: During the time that something is happening. [19]

examples.label: Until
examples.value: Up to the point in time that. [19]

examples.label: Since
examples.value: From a time in the past until now. [19]

examples.label: For
examples.value: Used to show a period of time. [14]

examples.label: Ago
examples.value: Before the present; in the past. [19]

examples.label: Later
examples.value: At a time in the future. [14]

examples.label: Early
examples.value: Before the usual or expected time. [4]

examples.label: Late
examples.value: After the usual or expected time. [4]

examples.label: When
examples.value: At or on which time. [19]

examples.label: As soon as
examples.value: Immediately at the moment that. [19]

examples.label: Meanwhile
examples.value: In the time between two events.

examples.label: Eventually
examples.value: In the end, especially after a long time.

usage_examples: Wash your hands before eating.
I will play after finishing my homework.
Don't talk during the class.
My mother was cooking while I was studying.
Wait until the rain stops.
He has been living here since 2010.
I waited for an hour.
He left two days ago.
I will call you later.
The farmer gets up early in the morning.
Why are you late for school?
I was happy when I heard the news.
Come home as soon as school is over.
You set the table. Meanwhile, I'll finish cooking.
After trying many times, he eventually succeeded.
